column4: just got home, the harddrive is connected to usb and power and the write protect switch is off
is the webcam plugged in? (/smartass answer)
when you say 'see'... as in show up in the Computer, or not at all (e.g. no /dev entry, if you know what that means?)
I wasn't paying attention to the channel.... did you paste in what dmesg had to say?
not yet
what's "fdisk -l /dev/sda" say?
sda is my main harddrive
whoops, was reading too quick.
try 'dmesg | tail -f' then unplug & re-add the usb drive -- does anything get printed out when you plug it in?
http://pastebin.com/GDRNLNj8
your dmesg didn't contain any mentions of finding sdb, so you're probably just looking at an empty file / disconnected device node? with fdisk... (quickly leaving stuff I'm comfortable with)
it's as if its power cable was disconnected :)
there's "seeing" and then there's seeing: even a fairly corrupt drive will usually get picked up one way or another in the kernel messages when it's plugged in
unplug it from the computer, run "dmesg | tail -f", then plug it in. Any *new* lines that happened at the same time you plug it in?
I was wrong with the dmesg... "tail -f /var/log/messages" should give what you want, though.
was that it? ... try with a known good USB storage device (another drive, or a thumbdrive) and you should see more.
there's usually some entries about recognizing a mass storage device and assigning it to /dev/sdb (or sdc, etc)
Yup. Hence.... I'm guessing there's something busted with it.
if the stuff on there is super important you can try moving it to a different enclosure to make sure it's the drive that's dead (and not the USB case around it)
bummer
USB enclosures are cheap;
also cheap are PCMCIA eSATA adapters for laptops
it was a hardware issue. the connections inside eroeded ayaw but i might be able to resoder tmem
good luck :) you may also be able to move the drive to a different case
